item.title: Covid: PM determined restrictions will end on 19 July
item.description: Current Covid measures will remain in England until then, but some Tory MPs fear it could be longer.

item.title: UK and Australia announce new trade deal
item.description: Downing Street says the pact means UK Scotch whisky and biscuits will be cheaper to sell to Australia.

item.title: UK jobs market 'showing signs of recovery'
item.description: The unemployment rate falls again while the number of job vacancies is rising, official figures show.

item.title: Christian Eriksen 'fine under circumstances' after cardiac arrest at Euro 2020
item.description: Denmark midfielder Christian Eriksen says he is "fine under the circumstances" as he continues his recovery from a cardiac arrest.

item.title: Covid-19: Boris Johnson determined over 19 July and capacity crowds for Wimbledon finals
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Tuesday morning.

item.title: US model Chrissy Teigen apologises for online 'trolling'
item.description: It comes a month after Teigen apologised to TV personality Courtney Stodden for online bullying.

item.title: Secrets of tiny diving mammals revealed
item.description: Biologists have uncovered the genetic secrets of water shrews, the world's smallest diving mammals.

item.title: Three things to watch as Joe Biden meets Vladimir Putin
item.description: The US president is set to talk to the Russian leader in Geneva, Switzerland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Self-harm warning signs can appear decade earlier
item.description: Even at age five, some children are more likely to self-harm than their classmates.

item.title: Victims of police domestic abuse 'feel silenced'
item.description: Officers accused of domestic abuse are not properly investigated, victims say.

item.title: Beijing tells Nato to stop hyping up China threat
item.description: It comes after a summit of alliance leaders described China's behaviour as a "systemic challenge".

item.title: Pangolin: How do you save the 'world’s most trafficked mammal'?
item.description: Thai has dedicated his life to educating the Vietnamese public about pangolin conservation.

item.title: Wedding can go ahead despite lockdown easing delay
item.description: Watch the moment a young couple find out they can have a full-scale wedding next week.

item.title: The Papers: 'Will we ever be free?' and 'vax to the future'
item.description: The decision to delay lifting the last coronavirus restrictions in England dominates Tuesday's papers.

item.title: The 'visual beauty' of bricked-up windows
item.description: Andy Billman's architectural photo series examines how light and air affect wellbeing.

item.title: Rare orchids found in City of London bank's rooftop garden
item.description: Usually seen in southern Europe, the plants have not been found in the wild in the UK for decades.

item.title: Great British Photography Challenge: BBC Four show crowns joint winners
item.description: Two Great British Photography Challenge hopefuls are named victors by Rankin and his fellow judges.

item.title: ‘Really, really rare’ seahorse spotted off UK coast
item.description: A marine biologist says it’s the first time he’s ever seen a long-snouted seahorse in the wild.

item.title: The gay men who can donate blood in the UK for the first time
item.description: Gay couple Oscar and Xavier donate blood for the first time after rules change across most of the UK.

item.title: Ethiopian migrants face robbery, extortion and starvation
item.description: Every year thousands of migrants risk it all on the perilous journey from Ethiopia to Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Christian Eriksen: Dad back playing football after cardiac arrest
item.description: Andrew Barnett had a cardiac arrest while playing football in front of his son in 2018.

item.title: Oops, wrong chair: Netanyahu sits in PM's chair after loss
item.description: After a vote installing a new government, Benjamin Netanyahu sat back down, but in a seat that was no longer his.

item.title: ASMR: Former farmer, 84, is accidental YouTube star
item.description: John Butler's videos have been watched by millions after he became popular with the ASMR community.

item.title: Christian Eriksen: What can cause a cardiac arrest?
item.description: Athletes can be more at risk because of stress on their hearts, but they can happen to anyone at any time.

item.title: Gigafactories: Europe tools up against US and Asia as a car battery force
item.description: As demand for electric cars grows, giant battery factories are being built across Europe.

item.title: Euro 2020: Scotland 0-2 Czech Republic - 'Painfully familiar, as Scots suffer again'
item.description: How Scotland's historic day of vibrant pageantry and football fever turned nightmarish at Hampden.

item.title: Nato and climate change: How big is the problem?
item.description: Allied members have agreed to "significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions from military activities".

item.title: Ethiopia's election 2021: A quick guide
item.description: Prime Minister and Nobel laureate Abiy Ahmed faces his first electoral test since taking office.

item.title: Coronavirus G7: Could a billion more vaccines for poorer countries make a difference?
item.description: How much difference could the G7 offer of a billion vaccines make to tackling the pandemic?

item.title: Nato summit: What does the US contribute?
item.description: President Biden is meeting Nato leaders to reaffirm the US commitment to the alliance.

item.title: The buzzwords reflecting the frustration of China's young generation
item.description: Millions in China are expressing their desire to break free of a standard definition of success.

item.title: 85% possession but no goals - should Spain be worried after slow start to Euros?
item.description: Are Spain in a spot of trouble after their Euro 2020 goalless draw with Sweden - or will they come good?

item.title: Capacity crowds to be allowed at Wimbledon men's and women's finals
item.description: Wimbledon's men's and women's finals will be played in front of full capacity crowds - the first UK outdoor sporting events to do so since the start of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: 'Eating pork can lead to a false positive' - US runner blames burrito for four-year ban
item.description: Shelby Houlihan says she has been banned for four years after testing positive for a prohibited substance - which she blames on a burrito.

item.title: From teenage tears to European champion: How Cristiano Ronaldo became a Euros legend
item.description: BBC Sport looks at Cristiano Ronaldo's journey at the European Championship, from teenage tears in 2004 against Greece, all the way through to winning the tournament as Portugal's captain at Euro 2016.

item.title: Euros On This Day - 15 June: Van Basten hat-trick, Gascoigne's Wembley glory and Welbeck's cheeky finish
item.description: BBC Sport rounds up the best archive action from 15 June in European Championship history.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The government has said some restrictions will stay in place in England after 21 June.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and can I hold a reception?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine is being offered to over-18s in Wales and Northern Ireland, over-25s in England and over-30s in Scotland.

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions in England has been delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 41 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid: Is there a limit to how much worse variants can get?
item.description: The coronavirus has changed and changed again, getting more transmissible each time.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: Covid symptoms: Is it a cold or coronavirus?
item.description: With similar symptoms, deciding whether or not you need to get tested for coronavirus can be tricky.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: How should I protect myself from Covid now?
item.description: What are the actions we can take to reduce our risk of catching the virus?

item.title: Lockdown easing: Four numbers to look for ahead of the 21 June decision
item.description: The key numbers that offer clues as to whether "freedom day" will proceed as planned on 21 June.

item.title: 'We want another homeless hotel - and we can make it work'
item.description: The Holiday Inn in Gorton, Manchester, housed homeless people throughout the pandemic, until the end of May.

item.title: 'Huntington's disease won't stop me having a baby'
item.description: Heather and her husband are going to have a baby, even though Heather's time with the child will be limited.

item.title: 'The 80s song that brought my lost memory back after 10 years'
item.description: A car crash erased Thomas's memory - 10 years later, a 1980s pop song triggered six flashbacks.

item.title: Myanmar: The mysterious deaths of the NLD party officials
item.description: The deaths of officials from Aung San Suu Kyi's party have raised scrutiny of the military's actions.

item.title: Freddie Figgers: The millionaire tech inventor who was 'thrown away' as a baby
item.description: Entrepreneur Freddie Figgers says life has taught him that the important thing is people, not profits.
